Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support For ACM SIGSOFT Symposium on the Foundations of Software Engineering (FSE 2014)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The grant provides student travel support to the Symposium on Foundations of Software Engineering (FSE 2014), to be held on November 11-16, 2014 in Hong Kong, China. This is one of the flagship conferences in the Software Engineering field for researchers and educators to present and discuss the most recent innovations, trends, experiences, etc. Funding for student travel has significant broader impacts because of the opportunity it gives the students to become part of the research community, discuss their research with others, listen to and meet with leaders in the field, and so on. This conference is international and takes place in China, which provides an international dimension, because students will have experiences relevant to becoming part of a global workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project manages to support 12 US students to participate FSE 2014, 2015 and 2016 held in Hong Kong (China), Bergamo (Italy), and Seattle (US), respectively.  Among the 12 students, 4 are undergraduates and 8 are PhD students; 3 are female students and 9 are male students. FSE, the ACM SIGSOFT Symposium on the Foundations of Software Engineering, is a premier software engineering conference, providing a forum for researchers, practitioners and educators to present and discuss the most recent innovations, trends, experiences and concerns in the field of software engineering. FSE provided the students with useful guidance and feedback on various aspects of their research from established researchers and the other student attendees. It also helped the students to establish a research and social network with their peers from around the world. In the long run, this project helps strengthen the domestic talent pool for software engineering that is traditionally weak and meet the desperate need of US economy for well-rounded software engineering researchers. The student grants were assigned mainly based on the merit, the financial need, and also the support letters written by academic advisers. Higher priority was assigned to students giving presentations and a strong emphasis was put on supporting students from underrepresented groups, including undergraduate students.
